user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtList_Destroy:
```c
void UtList_Destroy(UtListHead_t *ListHead)
{
    uint32 i;

    for (i = 0; i < ListHead->NumberOfTags; ++i)
    {
        UtList_Reset(&ListHead->Tags[i]);
    }
    free(ListHead);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UtList_Destroy:
void UtList_Reset(UtListNode_t *TagHead)
{
    while (!UtList_IsEmpty(TagHead))
    {
        UtList_DeleteNode(TagHead->Next);
    }
}
...
void UtList_DeleteNode(UtListNode_t *DeleteNode)
{
    UtList_Extract(DeleteNode);

    /* non-data/header nodes shouldn't be free()'ed */
    if (DeleteNode->Data != NULL)
    {
        free(DeleteNode);
    }
}
...
void UtTest_Run(void)
{
    UtListNode_t *         UtListMain;
    UtListNode_t *         UtListNode;
    UtTestDataBaseEntry_t *UtTestDataBaseEntry;

    UT_BSP_Lock();

    /*
     * The overall test sequence goes SETUP->TEST->TEARDOWN
     *
     * Combine all registered test groups into a merged group for execution.
     *
     * This could also (theoretically) randomize the order of the "TEST" group
     * while assembling this list, if there was a portable source of entropy.
     */
    UtListMain = UtList_GetHead(UtAssert_Global.DataBasePtr, UTASSERT_GROUP_DEFAULT);
    UtList_Merge(UtListMain, UtList_GetHead(UtAssert_Global.DataBasePtr, UTASSERT_GROUP_SETUP));
    UtList_Merge(UtListMain, UtList_GetHead(UtAssert_Global.DataBasePtr, UTASSERT_GROUP_TEST));
    UtList_Merge(UtListMain, UtList_GetHead(UtAssert_Global.DataBasePtr, UTASSERT_GROUP_TEARDOWN));

    UT_BSP_Unlock();

    /*
     * Run through the merged list in order
     */
    for (UtListNode = UtList_GetNext(UtListMain); !UtList_IsEnd(UtListMain, UtListNode);
         UtListNode = UtList_GetNext(UtListNode))
    {
        UtTestDataBaseEntry = UtList_GetObject(UtListNode);

        if (UtTestDataBaseEntry != NULL)
        {
            UtAssert_BeginTest(UtTestDataBaseEntry->TestName);

            UtAssert_SetContext(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TSF);
            if (UtTestDataBaseEntry->Setup)
            {
                UtTestDataBaseEntry->Setup();
            }
            UtAssert_SetContext(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_FAILURE);
            if (UtTestDataBaseEntry->Test)
            {
                UtTestDataBaseEntry->Test();
                UtAssert_Global.ExecutedCount++;
            }
            UtAssert_SetContext(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TTF);
            if (UtTestDataBaseEntry->Teardown)
            {
                UtTestDataBaseEntry->Teardown();
            }

            UtAssert_EndTest();
        }
    }

    UT_BSP_Lock();
    UtList_Destroy(UtAssert_Global.DataBasePtr);
    UT_BSP_Unlock();

    UT_BSP_EndTest(UtAssert_GetCounters());
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
The fragments not listed have been omitted because, based on the provided code, they do not themselves contain calls that could create a direct or indirect recursion cycle with the above functions (no evidence of self-calls or mutual calls is present in the supplied snippets). In particular:
- Calls to UT_BSP_Lock/Unlock and UT_BSP_EndTest/UtAssert_* are OS/test harness hooks and, as shown, are simple calls with no visible link back into the listed list-manipulation functions.
- The various accessor/manipulator calls referenced in UtTest_Run (UtList_GetHead, UtList_Merge, UtList_GetNext, UtList_IsEnd, UtList_GetObject) are only invoked by UtTest_Run in the shown code and their implementations were not provided; there is no evidence in the supplied code that they call back into UtList_Destroy/UtList_Reset/UtList_DeleteNode or form a recursive cycle, so they were not included here. These implementations should be inspected only if other agents find a call graph that suggests recursion.
- The free() calls themselves are standard deallocation calls and do not indicate recursion unless custom hooks (not shown) invoke back into the module; such hooks are outside the provided code and so are not listed.

The selected fragments include all code sites in the supplied snippets where calls occur that could participate in an indirect recursion (explicit internal calls and function-pointer invocations). Other fragments were excluded because the provided content contains no evidence they form recursive call chains with the listed functions.
